qas.question: Religious Ashkenazi Jews living in Israel follow the authority of whom in certain matters?
Religious Ashkenazi Jews look to the authority of the chief Ashkenazi rabbi in which matters?

context: Religious Ashkenazi Jews living in Israel are obliged to follow the authority of <a0_0>the chief Ashkenazi rabbi<a0_0/> in <a2_0>halakhic matters<a2_0/>. In this respect, a religiously Ashkenazi Jew is an Israeli who is more likely to support certain religious interests in Israel, including certain political parties. These political parties result from the fact that a portion of the Israeli electorate votes for Jewish religious parties; although the electoral map changes from one election to another, there are generally several small parties associated with the interests of religious Ashkenazi Jews. The role of religious parties, including small religious parties that play important roles as coalition members, results in turn from Israel's composition as a complex society in which competing social, economic, and religious interests stand for election to the Knesset, <a1_0>a unicameral legislature with 120 seats<a1_0/>.
